half the population that the very biological machinery
that perpetuates the species, that gives everything that we have, is somehow dirty or toxic. And I'm not going to stand for it. (Applause) And the way we break that curse? It's knowledge. Thank you. (Cheers and applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How much blood does the uterus hold during menstruation?
Options: A. 12 ounces, B. 100 to 120 milliliters, C. 30 to 90 milliliters, D. 7 liters
Correct Option: C

To create an obstacle course for the embryo to maximize the chance of a beneficial outcome, D. To reduce the risk of maternal mortality Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years ago,
the Romans invented a material that allowed them to build 
much of their sprawling civilization. Pliny the Elder praised an imposing
sea wall made from the stuff as “impregnable to the waves
and every day stronger.” He was right: much of this construction
still stands, having survived millennia of battering 
by environmental forces that would topple modern buildings. Today, our roads, sidewalks, bridges, 
and skyscrapers are made of a similar, though 
less durable, material called concrete. There’s three tons of it for every person 
on Earth. And over the next 40 years, 
we’ll use enough of it to build the equivalent of New York City 
every single month. Concrete has shaped our skylines, but that's not the only way
it's changed our world. It’s also played a surprisingly large role
in rising global temperatures over the last century, a trend that has already 
changed the world, and threatens to even more drastically
in the coming decades. To be fair to concrete, basically
everything humanity does contributes to the greenhouse gas 
emissions that cause global warming. Most of those emissions come 
from industrial processes we often aren’t aware of, 
but touch every aspect of our lives. Look around your home. Refrigeration— 
along with other heating and cooling— makes up about 6% of total emissions. Agriculture, which produces our food,
accounts for 18%. Electricity is responsible for 27%. Walk outside, and the cars zipping past,
planes overhead, trains ferrying commuters to work— transportation, including shipping, contributes 16% 
of greenhouse gas emissions. Even before we use any of these things,
making them produces emissions— a lot of emissions. Making materials— concrete, steel, plastic, glass, 
aluminum and everything else— accounts for 31%
of greenhouse gas emissions. Concrete alone is responsible for 8% 
of all carbon emissions worldwide. And it’s much more difficult to reduce 
the emissions from concrete than from other building materials. The problem is cement, 
one of the four ingredients in concrete. It holds the other three ingredients—
gravel, sand, and water— together. Unfortunately, it's impossible to make
cement without generating carbon dioxide. The essential ingredient in cement
is calcium oxide, CaO. We get that calcium oxide from limestone, which is mostly made of calcium carbonate:
CaCO3. We extract CaO from CaCO3
by heating limestone. What’s left is CO2— carbon dioxide. So for every ton of cement we produce,
we release one ton of carbon dioxide. As tricky as this problem is, it means concrete could help
us change the world a third time: by eliminating greenhouse gas emissions
and stabilizing our climate. Right now, there’s no 100% clean concrete, but there are some great ideas
to help us get there. Cement manufacturing also produces
greenhouse gas emissions by burning fossil fuels 
to heat the limestone. Heating the limestone with clean 
electricity or alternative fuels instead would eliminate those emissions. For the carbon dioxide from
the limestone itself, our best bet is carbon capture: specifically, capturing the carbon
right where it’s produced, before it enters the atmosphere. Devices that do this already exist, but they aren’t widely used because
there’s no economic incentive. Transporting and then storing 
the captured carbon can be expensive. To solve these problems, one company has found a way to store
captured CO2 permanently in the concrete itself. Other innovators are tinkering with 
the fundamental chemistry of concrete. Some are investigating ways 
to reduce emissions by decreasing the cement in concrete. Still others have been working
to uncover and replicate the secrets of Roman concrete. They found that Pliny’s remark 
is literally true. The Romans used volcanic ash 
in their cement. When the ash interacted with seawater,
the seawater strengthened it— making their concrete stronger and more 
long-lasting than any we use today. By adding these findings to an arsenal 
of modern innovations, hopefully we can replicate their success— both by making long lasting structures, and ensuring our descendants can admire
them thousands of years from now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: There are ____ of concrete per person in the world
Options: A. 500 pounds, B. 3 tons, C. 10 tons, D. 875 pounds
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What are the four main ingredients in concrete? Options: A. Cement, gravel, sand, and steel, B. Cement, gravel, sand, and water, C. Cement, limestone, sand, and water, D. Cement, volcanic ash, sand, and water Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the estimated amount of concrete that will be used over the next 40 years? Options: A. Enough to build the equivalent of New York City every year, B. Enough to build the equivalent of New York City every month, C. Enough to build the equivalent of New York City every decade, D. Enough to build the equivalent of New York City every century Correct Option: B
Question 3: How does the production of concrete affect greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. It reduces greenhouse gas emissions, B. It has no impact on greenhouse gas emissions, C. It contributes to greenhouse gas emissions, D. It eliminates greenhouse gas emissions Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is a significant contributor to greenhouse gas emissions in the production of concrete? Options: A. The extraction of limestone, B. The heating of limestone to produce cement, C. The mixing of cement, gravel, sand, and water, D. The transportation of concrete Correct Option: B
Question 5: A construction company wants to reduce its carbon footprint. Which of the following strategies could it use? Options: A. Increase the use of cement in its concrete mix, B. Implement carbon capture technology, C. Switch to renewable energy sources for heating limestone, D. Reduce the use of gravel in its concrete mix Correct Option: B
Question 6: A city wants to build more sustainable structures. Which of the following approaches could it take? Options: A. Incorporate Roman concrete principles into modern construction, B. Increase the use of steel in its buildings, C. Reduce the amount of cement in its concrete mix, D. Use alternative materials to replace concrete Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the cause-and-effect connection between the use of fossil fuels in cement manufacturing and greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. The use of fossil fuels reduces greenhouse gas emissions, B. The use of fossil fuels has no impact on greenhouse gas emissions, C. The use of fossil fuels contributes to greenhouse gas emissions, D. The use of fossil fuels eliminates greenhouse gas emissions Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the contrast between the durability of Roman concrete and modern concrete? Options: A. Roman concrete is less durable than modern concrete, B. Roman concrete is more durable than modern concrete, C. Roman concrete and modern concrete have the same durability, D. Roman concrete is only used for decorative purposes Correct Option: B
Question 9: A company wants to develop a new type of concrete that is more sustainable. Which of the following approaches could it take? Options: A. Combine Roman concrete principles with modern innovations, B. Increase the use of supplementary cementitious materials, C. Reduce the amount of cement in its concrete mix, D. Use alternative materials to replace concrete Correct Option: A
Question 10: A city wants to reduce its carbon footprint by integrating carbon capture technology with cement manufacturing. What could be a potential benefit of this approach? Options: A. Reduced greenhouse gas emissions, B. Increased production costs, C. Decreased durability of concrete, D. Increased use of fossil fuels Correct Option: A
Question 11: What are some key considerations when evaluating the effectiveness of different strategies for reducing emissions from cement production? Options: A. The cost of implementation, B. The environmental impact, C. The social impact, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 12: What is a potential trade-off of implementing carbon capture technology in cement manufacturing? Options: A. Reduced greenhouse gas emissions and lower production costs, B. Reduced greenhouse gas emissions and higher production costs, C. Increased greenhouse gas emissions and lower production costs, D. Increased greenhouse gas emissions and higher production costs Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ exactly. However, I can try to find the one that is closest in terms of question intent, options, and content.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the amount of concrete per person in the world. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs ask a similar question.

However, if I had to choose one that is vaguely related to the topic of concrete quantities, I would choose Question 2. This question asks about the estimated amount of concrete that will be used over the next 40 years, which is not directly related to the amount of concrete per person but is still related to concrete quantities.

So, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is: 2

Please note that this is a weak match, and it would be better to generate new MCQs that are more closely related to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years ago,
the Romans invented a material that allowed them to build 
much of their sprawling civilization. Pliny the Elder praised an imposing
sea wall made from the stuff as “impregnable to the waves
and every day stronger.” He was right: much of this construction
still stands, having survived millennia of battering 
by environmental forces that would topple modern buildings. Today, our roads, sidewalks, bridges, 
and skyscrapers are made of a similar, though 
less durable, material called concrete. There’s three tons of it for every person 
on Earth. And over the next 40 years, 
we’ll use enough of it to build the equivalent of New York City 
every single month. Concrete has shaped our skylines, but that's not the only way
it's changed our world. It’s also played a surprisingly large role
in rising global temperatures over the last century, a trend that has already 
changed the world, and threatens to even more drastically
in the coming decades. To be fair to concrete, basically
everything humanity does contributes to the greenhouse gas 
emissions that cause global warming. Most of those emissions come 
from industrial processes we often aren’t aware of, 
but touch every aspect of our lives. Look around your home. Refrigeration— 
along with other heating and cooling— makes up about 6% of total emissions. Agriculture, which produces our food,
accounts for 18%. Electricity is responsible for 27%. Walk outside, and the cars zipping past,
planes overhead, trains ferrying commuters to work— transportation, including shipping, contributes 16% 
of greenhouse gas emissions. Even before we use any of these things,
making them produces emissions— a lot of emissions. Making materials— concrete, steel, plastic, glass, 
aluminum and everything else— accounts for 31%
of greenhouse gas emissions. Concrete alone is responsible for 8% 
of all carbon emissions worldwide. And it’s much more difficult to reduce 
the emissions from concrete than from other building materials. The problem is cement, 
one of the four ingredients in concrete. It holds the other three ingredients—
gravel, sand, and water— together. Unfortunately, it's impossible to make
cement without generating carbon dioxide. The essential ingredient in cement
is calcium oxide, CaO. We get that calcium oxide from limestone, which is mostly made of calcium carbonate:
CaCO3. We extract CaO from CaCO3
by heating limestone. What’s left is CO2— carbon dioxide. So for every ton of cement we produce,
we release one ton of carbon dioxide. As tricky as this problem is, it means concrete could help
us change the world a third time: by eliminating greenhouse gas emissions
and stabilizing our climate. Right now, there’s no 100% clean concrete, but there are some great ideas
to help us get there. Cement manufacturing also produces
greenhouse gas emissions by burning fossil fuels 
to heat the limestone. Heating the limestone with clean 
electricity or alternative fuels instead would eliminate those emissions. For the carbon dioxide from
the limestone itself, our best bet is carbon capture: specifically, capturing the carbon
right where it’s produced, before it enters the atmosphere. Devices that do this already exist, but they aren’t widely used because
there’s no economic incentive. Transporting and then storing 
the captured carbon can be expensive. To solve these problems, one company has found a way to store
captured CO2 permanently in the concrete itself. Other innovators are tinkering with 
the fundamental chemistry of concrete. Some are investigating ways 
to reduce emissions by decreasing the cement in concrete. Still others have been working
to uncover and replicate the secrets of Roman concrete. They found that Pliny’s remark 
is literally true. The Romans used volcanic ash 
in their cement. When the ash interacted with seawater,
the seawater strengthened it— making their concrete stronger and more 
long-lasting than any we use today. By adding these findings to an arsenal 
of modern innovations, hopefully we can replicate their success— both by making long lasting structures, and ensuring our descendants can admire
them thousands of years from now.

Options: A. 8 percent, B. 31 percent, C. 55 percent, D. 6 percent
Correct Option: A

by heating limestone. What’s left is CO2— carbon dioxide. So for every ton of cement we produce,

and stabilizing our climate. Right now, there’s no 100% clean concrete, but there are some great ideas

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 4

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years ago,

to help us get there. Cement manufacturing also produces

the limestone itself, our best bet is carbon capture: specifically, capturing the carbon
right where it’s produced, before it enters the atmosphere. Devices that do this already exist, but they aren’t widely used because
there’s no economic incentive. Transporting and then storing 
the captured carbon can be expensive. To solve these problems, one company has found a way to store
captured CO2 permanently in the concrete itself. Other innovators are tinkering with

to reduce emissions by decreasing the cement in concrete. Still others have been working

of modern innovations, hopefully we can replicate their success— both by making long lasting structures, and ensuring our descendants can admire
them thousands of years from now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following compounds is essential in making cement:
Options: A. Carbon Dioxide, B. Calcium Oxide, C. Ozone, D. Hydrogen oxide
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:

The use of fossil fuels eliminates greenhouse gas emissions Correct Option: C

Roman concrete is more durable than modern concrete, C. Roman concrete and modern concrete have the same durability, D. Roman concrete is only used for decorative purposes Correct Option: B

Combine Roman concrete principles with modern innovations, B. Increase the use of supplementary cementitious materials, C. Reduce the amount of cement in its concrete mix, D. Use alternative materials to replace concrete Correct Option: A
Question 10: A city wants to reduce its carbon footprint by integrating carbon capture technology with cement manufacturing. What could be a potential benefit of this approach? Options: A. Reduced greenhouse gas emissions, B. Increased production costs, C. Decreased durability of concrete, D. Increased use of fossil fuels Correct Option: A
Question 11: What are some key considerations when evaluating the effectiveness of different strategies for reducing emissions from cement production? Options: A. The cost of implementation, B. The environmental impact, C. The social impact, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 12: What is a potential trade-off of implementing carbon capture technology in cement manufacturing? Options: A. Reduced greenhouse gas emissions and lower production costs, B. Reduced greenhouse gas emissions and higher production costs, C. Increased greenhouse gas emissions and lower production costs, D. Increased greenhouse gas emissions and higher production costs Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years ago,
the Romans invented a material that allowed them to build 
much of their sprawling civilization. Pliny the Elder praised an imposing
sea wall made from the stuff as “impregnable to the waves
and every day stronger.” He was right: much of this construction
still stands, having survived millennia of battering 
by environmental forces that would topple modern buildings. Today, our roads, sidewalks, bridges, 
and skyscrapers are made of a similar, though 
less durable, material called concrete. There’s three tons of it for every person 
on Earth. And over the next 40 years, 
we’ll use enough of it to build the equivalent of New York City 
every single month. Concrete has shaped our skylines, but that's not the only way
it's changed our world. It’s also played a surprisingly large role
in rising global temperatures over the last century, a trend that has already 
changed the world, and threatens to even more drastically
in the coming decades. To be fair to concrete, basically
everything humanity does contributes to the greenhouse gas 
emissions that cause global warming. Most of those emissions come 
from industrial processes we often aren’t aware of, 
but touch every aspect of our lives. Look around your home. Refrigeration— 
along with other heating and cooling— makes up about 6% of total emissions. Agriculture, which produces our food,
accounts for 18%. Electricity is responsible for 27%. Walk outside, and the cars zipping past,
planes overhead, trains ferrying commuters to work— transportation, including shipping, contributes 16% 
of greenhouse gas emissions. Even before we use any of these things,
making them produces emissions— a lot of emissions. Making materials— concrete, steel, plastic, glass, 
aluminum and everything else— accounts for 31%
of greenhouse gas emissions. Concrete alone is responsible for 8% 
of all carbon emissions worldwide. And it’s much more difficult to reduce 
the emissions from concrete than from other building materials. The problem is cement, 
one of the four ingredients in concrete. It holds the other three ingredients—
gravel, sand, and water— together. Unfortunately, it's impossible to make
cement without generating carbon dioxide. The essential ingredient in cement
is calcium oxide, CaO. We get that calcium oxide from limestone, which is mostly made of calcium carbonate:
CaCO3. We extract CaO from CaCO3
by heating limestone. What’s left is CO2— carbon dioxide. So for every ton of cement we produce,
we release one ton of carbon dioxide. As tricky as this problem is, it means concrete could help
us change the world a third time: by eliminating greenhouse gas emissions
and stabilizing our climate. Right now, there’s no 100% clean concrete, but there are some great ideas
to help us get there. Cement manufacturing also produces
greenhouse gas emissions by burning fossil fuels 
to heat the limestone. Heating the limestone with clean 
electricity or alternative fuels instead would eliminate those emissions. For the carbon dioxide from
the limestone itself, our best bet is carbon capture: specifically, capturing the carbon
right where it’s produced, before it enters the atmosphere. Devices that do this already exist, but they aren’t widely used because
there’s no economic incentive. Transporting and then storing 
the captured carbon can be expensive. To solve these problems, one company has found a way to store
captured CO2 permanently in the concrete itself. Other innovators are tinkering with 
the fundamental chemistry of concrete. Some are investigating ways 
to reduce emissions by decreasing the cement in concrete. Still others have been working
to uncover and replicate the secrets of Roman concrete. They found that Pliny’s remark 
is literally true. The Romans used volcanic ash 
in their cement. When the ash interacted with seawater,
the seawater strengthened it— making their concrete stronger and more 
long-lasting than any we use today. By adding these findings to an arsenal 
of modern innovations, hopefully we can replicate their success— both by making long lasting structures, and ensuring our descendants can admire
them thousands of years from now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or False: the ancient romans used volcanic ash and seawater to make concrete
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the estimated amount of concrete that will be used over the next 40 years? Options: A. Enough to build the equivalent of New York City every year, B. Reduced greenhouse gas emissions, B. Increased production costs, C. Decreased durability of concrete, D. Increased use of fossil fuels Correct Option: A

Reduced greenhouse gas emissions and higher production costs, C. Increased greenhouse gas emissions and lower production costs, D. Increased greenhouse gas emissions and higher production costs Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6. 

This question is about incorporating Roman concrete principles into modern construction, which is related to the fact that the ancient Romans used volcanic ash and seawater to make concrete. Although the options do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, the content and intent of the question are similar.

The generated MCQs cover various aspects of the transcript, but none of them specifically ask about the use of volcanic ash and seawater in Roman concrete.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As of 2020, the world’s biggest 
lithium-ion battery is hooked up to the Southern California 
power grid and can provide 250 million watts 
of power, or enough to power about 250,000 homes. But it’s actually not the biggest battery
in the world: these lakes are. Wait— how can a pair of lakes 
be a battery? To answer that question, 
it helps to define a battery: it’s simply something that stores energy
and releases it on demand. The lithium-ion batteries that power 
our phones, laptops, and cars are just one type. They store energy in lithium ions. To release the energy, the ions 
are separated from their electrons, then rejoined at the other end 
of the battery as a new molecule with lower energy. How do the two lakes 
store and release energy? First, one is 300 meters higher 
than the other. Electricity powers pumps that move
billions of liters of water from the lower lake to the higher one. This stores the energy by giving the water
extra gravitational potential energy. Then, when there’s high demand
for electricity, valves open, releasing the stored energy 
by letting water flow downhill to power 6 giant turbines that can 
generate 3 billion watts of power for 10 hours. We’re going to need more and more 
giant batteries. That’s because right now, generating
enough electricity to power the world produces an unsustainable amount 
of greenhouse gas: 14 billion tons per year. We’ll need to get that number 
down to net-zero. But many clean energy sources 
can’t produce electricity 24/7. So to make the switch, we need a way to
store the electricity until it's needed. That means we need grid-scale batteries: batteries big enough 
to power multiple cities. Unfortunately, neither of the giant
batteries we’ve talked about so far can solve this problem. The two lakes setup requires specific
geography, takes up a lot of land, and has high upfront costs to build. The giant lithium-ion battery
in California, meanwhile, can power about 250,000 homes, yes,
but only for an hour. Lithium-ion batteries are great for things
that don’t use a lot of power. But to store a lot of energy, 
they have to be huge and heavy. That’s why electric planes aren’t a thing: the best electric plane 
can only carry two people for about 1,000 kilometers on one charge, or its batteries would be too heavy 
to fly. A typical commercial jet can carry 
300 people over 14,000 km before refueling. Lithium-ion batteries also require 
certain heavy metals to make. These resources are limited, and mining
them often causes environmental damage. Inventors all over the world are rising 
to the challenge of making batteries that can meet 
our needs— many of them even weirder 
than the two lakes. One company is building 
a skyscraper battery. When the sun is shining, 
a crane powered by solar energy piles blocks on top of each other 
in a tower. At night, the cranes let gravity
pull the blocks down and use the resulting power 
to spin generators. Though there have been
some early setbacks, another promising approach involves
heating up salts until they melt. The molten salt can be stored until 
there’s a high demand for electricity, then used to boil water. The steam can power turbines
that generate electricity. Another idea: bio-batteries made 
from paper, powered by bacteria, and activated by spit. Bacteria release energy in the form 
of electrons when they metabolize glucose, and at least one species of bacteria can
transfer those electrons outside its cells,
completing a circuit. While these batteries won’t power
a city, or even a house, they don't have the waste and cost
concerns of traditional batteries. From vast mountain lakes 
to microscopic bacteria, from seawater batteries
that bypass the need for heavy metals to nuclear batteries
that power deep space missions, we're constantly rethinking
what a battery can be. The next unlikely battery could
be hiding in plain sight— just waiting to be discovered 
and help us achieve a sustainable future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 1. The world’s most powerful lithium-ion battery can generate ______ watts of power
Options: A. 250 Million , B. 150 Billion, C. 150 Million, D. 1 Billion, E. 3 Trillion
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the power capacity of the world's biggest lithium-ion battery connected to the Southern California power grid? Options: A. 100 million watts, B. 250 million watts, C. 500 million watts, D. 1 billion watts Correct Option: B
Question 2: How much greenhouse gas is currently produced per year to generate enough electricity to power the world? Options: A. 5 billion tons, B. 10 billion tons, C. 14 billion tons, D. 20 billion tons Correct Option: C
Question 3: What concept do the two lakes illustrate in the context of energy storage? Options: A. Kinetic energy conversion, B. Gravitational potential energy storage, C. Chemical energy storage, D. Thermal energy storage Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why are lithium-ion batteries less suitable for large-scale energy storage? Options: A. Due to their high energy density, B. Because of their long lifespan, C. Due to their size, weight, and resource requirements, D. Because of their low cost Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is a potential application of the two-lake system as a model for energy storage? Options: A. Powering small homes in remote areas, B. Supporting widespread adoption of clean energy sources, C. Providing backup power for data centers, D. Powering electric vehicles Correct Option: B
Question 6: How can energy storage solutions be integrated into existing power grids to improve efficiency? Options: A. By replacing traditional power plants, B. By providing backup power during outages, C. By storing excess energy generated by clean energy sources, D. By increasing energy consumption Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between energy storage capacity and greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. As energy storage capacity increases, greenhouse gas emissions increase, B. As energy storage capacity increases, greenhouse gas emissions remain the same, C. As energy storage capacity increases, greenhouse gas emissions can decrease, D. As energy storage capacity decreases, greenhouse gas emissions decrease Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a trade-off between lithium-ion batteries and other battery technologies, such as the two-lake system? Options: A. Size and weight vs. energy density, B. Cost vs. lifespan, C. Environmental impact vs. energy storage capacity, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What could be a potential benefit of combining the concept of the two-lake system with other energy storage technologies? Options: A. Increased energy storage capacity, B. Improved efficiency, C. Reduced environmental impact, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What could be a potential outcome of developing new battery technologies that address the limitations of existing technologies? Options: A. Increased reliance on fossil fuels, B. Reduced energy storage capacity, C. Improved efficiency and reduced environmental impact, D. Increased greenhouse gas emissions Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is a justification for investing in new battery technologies to support a sustainable future? Options: A. The high cost of existing battery technologies, B. The limitations of lithium-ion batteries, C. The need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and support widespread adoption of clean energy sources, D. The lack of energy storage capacity Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is a criterion for evaluating the effectiveness of different battery technologies in reducing greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. Energy storage capacity, B. Cost, C. Environmental impact, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Generated MCQ 1:** What is the power capacity of the world's biggest lithium-ion battery connected to the Southern California power grid? 
Options: A. 100 million watts, B. 250 million watts, C. 500 million watts, D. 1 billion watts 
Correct Option: B

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the power capacity of the world's most powerful/biggest lithium-ion battery, and both have similar answer options.

**Index of the most similar generated MCQ:** 1

and help us achieve a sustainable future.

in the world: these lakes are. Wait— how can a pair of lakes

it helps to define a battery: it’s simply something that stores energy
and releases it on demand. The lithium-ion batteries that power

of the battery as a new molecule with lower energy. How do the two lakes

than the other. Electricity powers pumps that move
billions of liters of water from the lower lake to the higher one. This stores the energy by giving the water

can’t produce electricity 24/7. So to make the switch, we need a way to
store the electricity until it's needed. That means we need grid-scale batteries: batteries big enough 
to power multiple cities. Unfortunately, neither of the giant
batteries we’ve talked about so far can solve this problem. The two lakes setup requires specific
geography, takes up a lot of land, and has high upfront costs to build. The giant lithium-ion battery
in California, meanwhile, can power about 250,000 homes, yes,
but only for an hour. Lithium-ion batteries are great for things
that don’t use a lot of power. But to store a lot of energy, 
they have to be huge and heavy. That’s why electric planes aren’t a thing: the best electric plane 
can only carry two people for about 1,000 kilometers on one charge, or its batteries would be too heavy 
to fly. A typical commercial jet can carry 
300 people over 14,000 km before refueling. Lithium-ion batteries also require 
certain heavy metals to make. These resources are limited, and mining
them often causes environmental damage. Inventors all over the world are rising 
to the challenge of making batteries that can meet 
our needs— many of them even weirder 
than the two lakes. One company is building 
a skyscraper battery. When the sun is shining, 
a crane powered by solar energy piles blocks on top of each other 
in a tower. At night, the cranes let gravity
pull the blocks down and use the resulting power 
to spin generators. Though there have been
some early setbacks, another promising approach involves
heating up salts until they melt. The molten salt can be stored until 
there’s a high demand for electricity, then used to boil water. The steam can power turbines
that generate electricity. Another idea: bio-batteries made 
from paper, powered by bacteria, and activated by spit. Bacteria release energy in the form 
of electrons when they metabolize glucose, and at least one species of bacteria can
transfer those electrons outside its cells,
completing a circuit. While these batteries won’t power
a city, or even a house, they don't have the waste and cost
concerns of traditional batteries. From vast mountain lakes 
to microscopic bacteria, from seawater batteries
that bypass the need for heavy metals to nuclear batteries
that power deep space missions, we're constantly rethinking
what a battery can be. The next unlikely battery could
be hiding in plain sight— just waiting to be discovered 
and help us achieve a sustainable future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What’s the definition of a battery?
Options: A. Electrical grid that delivers electricity, B. The capacity to exert power, C. Something that stores and releases energy on demand
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the power capacity of the world's biggest lithium-ion battery connected to the Southern California power grid? Options: A. 100 million watts, B. 250 million watts, C. 500 million watts, D. 1 billion watts Correct Option: B
Question 2: How much greenhouse gas is currently produced per year to generate enough electricity to power the world? Options: A. 5 billion tons, B. 10 billion tons, C. 14 billion tons, D. 20 billion tons Correct Option: C
Question 3: What concept do the two lakes illustrate in the context of energy storage? Options: A. Kinetic energy conversion, B. Gravitational potential energy storage, C. Chemical energy storage, D. Thermal energy storage Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why are lithium-ion batteries less suitable for large-scale energy storage? Options: A. Due to their high energy density, B. Because of their long lifespan, C. Due to their size, weight, and resource requirements, D. Because of their low cost Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is a potential application of the two-lake system as a model for energy storage? Options: A. Powering small homes in remote areas, B. Supporting widespread adoption of clean energy sources, C. Providing backup power for data centers, D. Powering electric vehicles Correct Option: B
Question 6: How can energy storage solutions be integrated into existing power grids to improve efficiency? Options: A. By replacing traditional power plants, B. As energy storage capacity decreases, greenhouse gas emissions decrease Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a trade-off between lithium-ion batteries and other battery technologies, such as the two-lake system? Options: A. Size and weight vs. energy density, B. Cost vs. lifespan, C. Environmental impact vs. energy storage capacity, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Question 10: What could be a potential outcome of developing new battery technologies that address the limitations of existing technologies? Options: A. Increased reliance on fossil fuels, B. Reduced energy storage capacity, C. Improved efficiency and reduced environmental impact, D. Increased greenhouse gas emissions Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is a justification for investing in new battery technologies to support a sustainable future? Options: A. The high cost of existing battery technologies, B. The limitations of lithium-ion batteries, C. The need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and support widespread adoption of clean energy sources, D. The lack of energy storage capacity Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is a criterion for evaluating the effectiveness of different battery technologies in reducing greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. Energy storage capacity, B. Cost, C. Environmental impact, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the concept of a battery.

The ground truth MCQ asks for the definition of a battery, and the correct option is "Something that stores and releases energy on demand."

Among the generated MCQs, Question 3 is the most relevant, as it asks about the concept illustrated by the two lakes in the context of energy storage. Although it doesn't directly ask for the definition of a battery, it is related to the idea of energy storage, which is a key aspect of a battery.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is more closely related to the definition of a battery, I would suggest Question 8. This option is somewhat related to the idea of a battery as something that stores and releases energy.

But, if I'm being completely honest, none of the generated MCQs are a great match for the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As of 2020, the world’s biggest 
lithium-ion battery is hooked up to the Southern California 
power grid and can provide 250 million watts 
of power, or enough to power about 250,000 homes. But it’s actually not the biggest battery
in the world: these lakes are. Wait— how can a pair of lakes 
be a battery? To answer that question, 
it helps to define a battery: it’s simply something that stores energy
and releases it on demand. The lithium-ion batteries that power 
our phones, laptops, and cars are just one type. They store energy in lithium ions. To release the energy, the ions 
are separated from their electrons, then rejoined at the other end 
of the battery as a new molecule with lower energy. How do the two lakes 
store and release energy? First, one is 300 meters higher 
than the other. Electricity powers pumps that move
billions of liters of water from the lower lake to the higher one. This stores the energy by giving the water
extra gravitational potential energy. Then, when there’s high demand
for electricity, valves open, releasing the stored energy 
by letting water flow downhill to power 6 giant turbines that can 
generate 3 billion watts of power for 10 hours. We’re going to need more and more 
giant batteries. That’s because right now, generating
enough electricity to power the world produces an unsustainable amount 
of greenhouse gas: 14 billion tons per year. We’ll need to get that number 
down to net-zero. But many clean energy sources 
can’t produce electricity 24/7. So to make the switch, we need a way to
store the electricity until it's needed. That means we need grid-scale batteries: batteries big enough 
to power multiple cities. Unfortunately, neither of the giant
batteries we’ve talked about so far can solve this problem. The two lakes setup requires specific
geography, takes up a lot of land, and has high upfront costs to build. The giant lithium-ion battery
in California, meanwhile, can power about 250,000 homes, yes,
but only for an hour. Lithium-ion batteries are great for things
that don’t use a lot of power. But to store a lot of energy, 
they have to be huge and heavy. That’s why electric planes aren’t a thing: the best electric plane 
can only carry two people for about 1,000 kilometers on one charge, or its batteries would be too heavy 
to fly. A typical commercial jet can carry 
300 people over 14,000 km before refueling. Lithium-ion batteries also require 
certain heavy metals to make. These resources are limited, and mining
them often causes environmental damage. Inventors all over the world are rising 
to the challenge of making batteries that can meet 
our needs— many of them even weirder 
than the two lakes. One company is building 
a skyscraper battery. When the sun is shining, 
a crane powered by solar energy piles blocks on top of each other 
in a tower. At night, the cranes let gravity
pull the blocks down and use the resulting power 
to spin generators. Though there have been
some early setbacks, another promising approach involves
heating up salts until they melt. The molten salt can be stored until 
there’s a high demand for electricity, then used to boil water. The steam can power turbines
that generate electricity. Another idea: bio-batteries made 
from paper, powered by bacteria, and activated by spit. Bacteria release energy in the form 
of electrons when they metabolize glucose, and at least one species of bacteria can
transfer those electrons outside its cells,
completing a circuit. While these batteries won’t power
a city, or even a house, they don't have the waste and cost
concerns of traditional batteries. From vast mountain lakes 
to microscopic bacteria, from seawater batteries
that bypass the need for heavy metals to nuclear batteries
that power deep space missions, we're constantly rethinking
what a battery can be. The next unlikely battery could
be hiding in plain sight— just waiting to be discovered 
and help us achieve a sustainable future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why aren’t lithium-ion batteries good for storing lots of energy?
Options: A. They expire after frequent use, B. They have to be huge and heavy, C. They don’t release all their stored energy, D. They need to be recharged frequently
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the power capacity of the world's biggest lithium-ion battery connected to the Southern California power grid? Options: A. 100 million watts, B. 250 million watts, C. 500 million watts, D. 1 billion watts Correct Option: B
Question 2: How much greenhouse gas is currently produced per year to generate enough electricity to power the world? Options: A. 5 billion tons, B. 10 billion tons, C. 14 billion tons, D. 20 billion tons Correct Option: C
Question 3: What concept do the two lakes illustrate in the context of energy storage? Options: A. Kinetic energy conversion, B. Gravitational potential energy storage, C. Chemical energy storage, D. Thermal energy storage Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why are lithium-ion batteries less suitable for large-scale energy storage? Options: A. Due to their high energy density, B. Because of their long lifespan, C. Due to their size, weight, and resource requirements, D. Because of their low cost Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is a potential application of the two-lake system as a model for energy storage? Options: A. Powering small homes in remote areas, B. Supporting widespread adoption of clean energy sources, C. Providing backup power for data centers, D. Powering electric vehicles Correct Option: B
Question 6: How can energy storage solutions be integrated into existing power grids to improve efficiency? Options: A. By replacing traditional power plants, B. By providing backup power during outages, C. By storing excess energy generated by clean energy sources, D. By increasing energy consumption Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the relationship between energy storage capacity and greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. As energy storage capacity increases, greenhouse gas emissions increase, B. As energy storage capacity increases, greenhouse gas emissions remain the same, C. As energy storage capacity increases, greenhouse gas emissions can decrease, D. As energy storage capacity decreases, greenhouse gas emissions decrease Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a trade-off between lithium-ion batteries and other battery technologies, such as the two-lake system? Options: A. Size and weight vs. energy density, B. Cost vs. lifespan, C. Environmental impact vs. energy storage capacity, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What could be a potential benefit of combining the concept of the two-lake system with other energy storage technologies? Options: A. Increased energy storage capacity, B. Improved efficiency, C. Reduced environmental impact, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What could be a potential outcome of developing new battery technologies that address the limitations of existing technologies? Options: A. Increased reliance on fossil fuels, B. Reduced energy storage capacity, C. Improved efficiency and reduced environmental impact, D. Increased greenhouse gas emissions Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is a justification for investing in new battery technologies to support a sustainable future? Options: A. The high cost of existing battery technologies, B. The limitations of lithium-ion batteries, C. The need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and support widespread adoption of clean energy sources, D. The lack of energy storage capacity Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is a criterion for evaluating the effectiveness of different battery technologies in reducing greenhouse gas emissions? Options: A. Energy storage capacity, B. Cost, C. Environmental impact, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, as both questions are asking about the limitations of lithium-ion batteries. The options for Question 4 also align with the correct answer for the ground truth MCQ, which is that lithium-ion batteries have to be huge and heavy to store a lot of energy.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: All of the following are examples of batteries, except:
Options: A. A crane linked to a tower , B. Melted salts, C. Floor rugs, D. Bacteria on paper activated by spit
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Two frogs are minding their own business
in the swamp when WHAM— they’re kidnapped. They come to in a kitchen, 
captives of a menacing chef. He boils up a pot of water 
and lobs one of the frogs in. But it’s having none of this. The second its toes hit the scalding water
it jumps right out the window. The chef refills the pot, but this time 
he doesn’t turn on the heat. He plops the second frog in,
and this frog’s okay with that. The chef turns the heat on, very low, 
and the temperature of water slowly rises. So slowly that the frog doesn’t notice. In fact, it basks in the balmy water. Only when the surface begins to bubble
does the frog realize: it’s toast. What’s funny about this parable is that
it’s not scientifically true... for frogs. In reality, a frog will detect slowly
heating water and leap to safety. Humans, on the other hand,
are a different story. We’re perfectly happy to sit in the pot 
and slowly turn up the heat, all the while insisting it isn’t our hand
on the dial, arguing about whether we can 
trust thermometers, and questioning— 
even if they’re right, does it matter? It does. Since 1850, global average temperatures 
have risen by 1 degree Celsius. That may not sound like a lot, but it is. Why? 1 degree is an average. Many places have already gotten
much warmer than that. Some places in the Arctic 
have already warmed 4 degrees. If global average temperatures 
increase 1 more degree, the coldest nights in the Arctic
might get 10 degrees warmer. The warmest days in Mumbai 
might get 5 degrees hotter. So how did we get here? Almost everything that makes modern life
possible relies on fossil fuels: coal, oil, and gas full of carbon 
from ancient organic matter. When we burn fossil fuels, we release carbon dioxide 
that builds up in our atmosphere, where it remains for hundreds 
or even thousands of years, letting heat in, but not out. The heat comes from sunlight, which passes
through the atmosphere to Earth, where it gets absorbed 
and warms everything up. Warm objects emit infrared radiation,
which should pass back out into space, because most atmospheric gases 
don’t absorb it. But greenhouse gases—
carbon dioxide and methane— do absorb infrared wavelengths. So when we add more of those gases 
to the atmosphere, less heat makes it back out to space, 
and our planet warms up. If we keep emitting greenhouse gases 
at our current pace, scientists predict temperatures
will rise 4 degrees from their pre-industrial levels by 2100. They’ve identified 1.5 degrees of warming— global averages half a degree warmer 
than today’s— as a threshold beyond which 
the negative impacts of climate change will become increasingly severe. To keep from crossing that threshold, we need to get our greenhouse gas 
emissions down to zero as fast as possible. Or rather, we have to get emissions
down to what's called net zero, meaning we may still be putting some
greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, but we take out as much as we put in. This doesn’t mean we can just keep 
emitting and sequester all that carbon— we couldn’t keep up with our emissions 
through natural methods, and technological solutions would
be prohibitively expensive and require huge amounts
of permanent storage. Instead, while we switch 
from coal, oil, and natural gas to clean energy and fuels, 
which will take time, we can mitigate the damage by removing
carbon from the atmosphere. Jumping out of the proverbial pot 
isn’t an option, but we can do something the frogs can’t: reach over, and turn down the heat.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Since 1850, global temperatures have increased by an average of:
Options: A. 1 Degree Fahrenheit, B. 3 Degrees Celsius, C. 1 Degree Celsius, D. 10 Degree Fahrenheit
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated global average temperature rise since 1850? Options: A. 0.5 degrees Celsius, B. 1 degree Celsius, C. 1.5 degrees Celsius, D. 2 degrees Celsius Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to scientists, what is the predicted temperature rise from pre-industrial levels by 2100 if greenhouse gas emissions continue at the current pace? Options: A. 2 degrees Celsius, B. 3 degrees Celsius, C. 4 degrees Celsius, D. 5 degrees Celsius Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the main purpose of using the parable of the frogs in the context of climate change? Options: A. To illustrate the effects of climate change on ecosystems, B. To demonstrate the importance of scientific research on climate change, C. To illustrate human behavior in the face of gradual changes, such as climate change, D. To highlight the role of individual actions in mitigating climate change Correct Option: C
Question 4: What does the concept of "net zero emissions" refer to? Options: A. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions to zero immediately, B. Balancing the amount of greenhouse gases emitted and removed from the atmosphere, C. Increasing the use of fossil fuels to meet energy demands, D. Implementing policies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions only Correct Option: B
Question 5: How can the concept of net zero emissions be achieved in real-world scenarios? Options: A. By transitioning to clean energy sources and balancing emissions and removals, B. By increasing the use of fossil fuels and implementing policies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, C. By reducing energy consumption only, D. By relying solely on natural methods to remove greenhouse gases Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is an example of observing the effects of climate change in different regions? Options: A. Comparing the effects of climate change in the Arctic and the Amazon rainforest, B. Studying the effects of climate change on polar bear populations only, C. Analyzing the effects of climate change in the Arctic and Mumbai, D. Examining the effects of climate change on coral reefs only Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the cause-and-effect connection between burning fossil fuels and global warming? Options: A. Burning fossil fuels releases oxygen, which cools the planet, B. Burning fossil fuels releases carbon dioxide, which absorbs infrared wavelengths and warms the planet, C. Burning fossil fuels has no effect on global warming, D. Burning fossil fuels releases methane, which is the primary cause of global warming Correct Option: B
Question 8: (Removed due to duplication with question 7) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the relationship between greenhouse gases and the trapping of heat in the atmosphere? Options: A. Greenhouse gases absorb infrared wavelengths and cool the planet, B. Greenhouse gases absorb infrared wavelengths and warm the planet, C. Greenhouse gases have no effect on the trapping of heat in the atmosphere, D. Greenhouse gases release heat from the atmosphere Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a crucial step in mitigating climate change? Options: A. Increasing the use of fossil fuels and implementing policies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, B. Transitioning to clean energy sources and balancing emissions and removals, C. Reducing energy consumption only, D. Implementing policies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions only Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is the most urgent action needed to mitigate climate change? Options: A. Reducing energy consumption only, B. Implementing policies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions only, C. Transitioning to clean energy sources to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, D. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions through multiple strategies, including transitioning to clean energy sources and balancing emissions and removals Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (asking about the average global temperature rise since 1850), options (providing a range of possible temperature increases), and content (focusing on the specific time frame and metric mentioned in the ground truth MCQ).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Two frogs are minding their own business
in the swamp when WHAM— they’re kidnapped. They come to in a kitchen, 
captives of a menacing chef. He boils up a pot of water 
and lobs one of the frogs in. But it’s having none of this. The second its toes hit the scalding water
it jumps right out the window. The chef refills the pot, but this time 
he doesn’t turn on the heat. He plops the second frog in,
and this frog’s okay with that. The chef turns the heat on, very low, 
and the temperature of water slowly rises. So slowly that the frog doesn’t notice. In fact, it basks in the balmy water. Only when the surface begins to bubble
does the frog realize: it’s toast. What’s funny about this parable is that
it’s not scientifically true... for frogs. In reality, a frog will detect slowly
heating water and leap to safety. Humans, on the other hand,
are a different story. We’re perfectly happy to sit in the pot 
and slowly turn up the heat, all the while insisting it isn’t our hand
on the dial, arguing about whether we can 
trust thermometers, and questioning— 
even if they’re right, does it matter? It does. Since 1850, global average temperatures 
have risen by 1 degree Celsius. That may not sound like a lot, but it is. Why? 1 degree is an average. Many places have already gotten
much warmer than that. Some places in the Arctic 
have already warmed 4 degrees. If global average temperatures 
increase 1 more degree, the coldest nights in the Arctic
might get 10 degrees warmer. The warmest days in Mumbai 
might get 5 degrees hotter. So how did we get here? Almost everything that makes modern life
possible relies on fossil fuels: coal, oil, and gas full of carbon 
from ancient organic matter. When we burn fossil fuels, we release carbon dioxide 
that builds up in our atmosphere, where it remains for hundreds 
or even thousands of years, letting heat in, but not out. The heat comes from sunlight, which passes
through the atmosphere to Earth, where it gets absorbed 
and warms everything up. Warm objects emit infrared radiation,
which should pass back out into space, because most atmospheric gases 
don’t absorb it. But greenhouse gases—
carbon dioxide and methane— do absorb infrared wavelengths. So when we add more of those gases 
to the atmosphere, less heat makes it back out to space, 
and our planet warms up. If we keep emitting greenhouse gases 
at our current pace, scientists predict temperatures
will rise 4 degrees from their pre-industrial levels by 2100. They’ve identified 1.5 degrees of warming— global averages half a degree warmer 
than today’s— as a threshold beyond which 
the negative impacts of climate change will become increasingly severe. To keep from crossing that threshold, we need to get our greenhouse gas 
emissions down to zero as fast as possible. Or rather, we have to get emissions
down to what's called net zero, meaning we may still be putting some
greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, but we take out as much as we put in. This doesn’t mean we can just keep 
emitting and sequester all that carbon— we couldn’t keep up with our emissions 
through natural methods, and technological solutions would
be prohibitively expensive and require huge amounts
of permanent storage. Instead, while we switch 
from coal, oil, and natural gas to clean energy and fuels, 
which will take time, we can mitigate the damage by removing
carbon from the atmosphere. Jumping out of the proverbial pot 
isn’t an option, but we can do something the frogs can’t: reach over, and turn down the heat.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following are greenhouse gases
Options: A. Methane and Oxygen, B. Nitrogen and Oxygen, C. Carbon Dioxide and Nitrogen, D. Methane and Carbon Dioxide
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated global average temperature rise since 1850? Options: A. 0.5 degrees Celsius, B. 1 degree Celsius, C. 1.5 degrees Celsius, D. 2 degrees Celsius Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to scientists, what is the predicted temperature rise from pre-industrial levels by 2100 if greenhouse gas emissions continue at the current pace? Options: A. 2 degrees Celsius, B. 3 degrees Celsius, C. 4 degrees Celsius, D. 5 degrees Celsius Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the main purpose of using the parable of the frogs in the context of climate change? Options: A. To illustrate the effects of climate change on ecosystems, B. To demonstrate the importance of scientific research on climate change, C. To illustrate human behavior in the face of gradual changes, such as climate change, D. To highlight the role of individual actions in mitigating climate change Correct Option: C
Question 4: What does the concept of "net zero emissions" refer to? Options: A. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions to zero immediately, B. Balancing the amount of greenhouse gases emitted and removed from the atmosphere, C. Increasing the use of fossil fuels to meet energy demands, D. Implementing policies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions only Correct Option: B
Question 5: How can the concept of net zero emissions be achieved in real-world scenarios? Options: A. By transitioning to clean energy sources and balancing emissions and removals, B. By increasing the use of fossil fuels and implementing policies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, C. By reducing energy consumption only, D. By relying solely on natural methods to remove greenhouse gases Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is an example of observing the effects of climate change in different regions? Options: A. Comparing the effects of climate change in the Arctic and the Amazon rainforest, B. Studying the effects of climate change on polar bear populations only, C. Analyzing the effects of climate change in the Arctic and Mumbai, D. Examining the effects of climate change on coral reefs only Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the cause-and-effect connection between burning fossil fuels and global warming? Options: A. Burning fossil fuels releases oxygen, which cools the planet, B. Burning fossil fuels releases carbon dioxide, which absorbs infrared wavelengths and warms the planet, C. Burning fossil fuels has no effect on global warming, D. Burning fossil fuels releases methane, which is the primary cause of global warming Correct Option: B
Question 8: (Removed due to duplication with question 7) Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the relationship between greenhouse gases and the trapping of heat in the atmosphere? Options: A. Greenhouse gases absorb infrared wavelengths and cool the planet, B. Greenhouse gases absorb infrared wavelengths and warm the planet, C. Greenhouse gases have no effect on the trapping of heat in the atmosphere, D. Greenhouse gases release heat from the atmosphere Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a crucial step in mitigating climate change? Options: A. Increasing the use of fossil fuels and implementing policies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, B. Transitioning to clean energy sources and balancing emissions and removals, C. Reducing energy consumption only, D. Implementing policies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions only Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is the most urgent action needed to mitigate climate change? Options: A. Reducing energy consumption only, B. Implementing policies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions only, C. Transitioning to clean energy sources to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, D. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions through multiple strategies, including transitioning to clean energy sources and balancing emissions and removals Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Greenhouse gases release heat from the atmosphere Correct Option: B**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Two frogs are minding their own business
in the swamp when WHAM— they’re kidnapped. They come to in a kitchen, 
captives of a menacing chef. He boils up a pot of water 
and lobs one of the frogs in. But it’s having none of this. The second its toes hit the scalding water
it jumps right out the window. The chef refills the pot, but this time 
he doesn’t turn on the heat. He plops the second frog in,
and this frog’s okay with that. The chef turns the heat on, very low, 
and the temperature of water slowly rises. So slowly that the frog doesn’t notice. In fact, it basks in the balmy water. Only when the surface begins to bubble
does the frog realize: it’s toast. What’s funny about this parable is that
it’s not scientifically true... for frogs. In reality, a frog will detect slowly
heating water and leap to safety. Humans, on the other hand,
are a different story. We’re perfectly happy to sit in the pot 
and slowly turn up the heat, all the while insisting it isn’t our hand
on the dial, arguing about whether we can 
trust thermometers, and questioning— 
even if they’re right, does it matter? It does. Since 1850, global average temperatures 
have risen by 1 degree Celsius. That may not sound like a lot, but it is. Why? 1 degree is an average. Many places have already gotten
much warmer than that. Some places in the Arctic 
have already warmed 4 degrees. If global average temperatures 
increase 1 more degree, the coldest nights in the Arctic
might get 10 degrees warmer. The warmest days in Mumbai 
might get 5 degrees hotter. So how did we get here? Almost everything that makes modern life
possible relies on fossil fuels: coal, oil, and gas full of carbon 
from ancient organic matter. When we burn fossil fuels, we release carbon dioxide 
that builds up in our atmosphere, where it remains for hundreds 
or even thousands of years, letting heat in, but not out. The heat comes from sunlight, which passes
through the atmosphere to Earth, where it gets absorbed 
and warms everything up. Warm objects emit infrared radiation,
which should pass back out into space, because most atmospheric gases 
don’t absorb it. But greenhouse gases—
carbon dioxide and methane— do absorb infrared wavelengths. So when we add more of those gases 
to the atmosphere, less heat makes it back out to space, 
and our planet warms up. If we keep emitting greenhouse gases 
at our current pace, scientists predict temperatures
will rise 4 degrees from their pre-industrial levels by 2100. They’ve identified 1.5 degrees of warming— global averages half a degree warmer 
than today’s— as a threshold beyond which 
the negative impacts of climate change will become increasingly severe. To keep from crossing that threshold, we need to get our greenhouse gas 
emissions down to zero as fast as possible. Or rather, we have to get emissions
down to what's called net zero, meaning we may still be putting some
greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, but we take out as much as we put in. This doesn’t mean we can just keep 
emitting and sequester all that carbon— we couldn’t keep up with our emissions 
through natural methods, and technological solutions would
be prohibitively expensive and require huge amounts
of permanent storage. Instead, while we switch 
from coal, oil, and natural gas to clean energy and fuels, 
which will take time, we can mitigate the damage by removing
carbon from the atmosphere. Jumping out of the proverbial pot 
isn’t an option, but we can do something the frogs can’t: reach over, and turn down the heat.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Scientists predict global average temperatures will rise by 4 degrees from preindustrial level by ____ if our current greenhouse gas emissions persist.
Options: A. 2050, B. 2100, C. 2033, D. 2200
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 4

**Transcript**:
Two frogs are minding their own business
in the swamp when WHAM— they’re kidnapped. They come to in a kitchen, 
captives of a menacing chef. He boils up a pot of water 
and lobs one of the frogs in. But it’s having none of this. The second its toes hit the scalding water
it jumps right out the window. The chef refills the pot, but this time 
he doesn’t turn on the heat. He plops the second frog in,
and this frog’s okay with that. The chef turns the heat on, very low, 
and the temperature of water slowly rises. So slowly that the frog doesn’t notice. In fact, it basks in the balmy water. Only when the surface begins to bubble
does the frog realize: it’s toast. What’s funny about this parable is that
it’s not scientifically true... for frogs. In reality, a frog will detect slowly
heating water and leap to safety. Humans, on the other hand,
are a different story. We’re perfectly happy to sit in the pot 
and slowly turn up the heat, all the while insisting it isn’t our hand
on the dial, arguing about whether we can 
trust thermometers, and questioning— 
even if they’re right, does it matter? It does. Since 1850, global average temperatures 
have risen by 1 degree Celsius. That may not sound like a lot, but it is. Why? 1 degree is an average. Many places have already gotten
much warmer than that. Some places in the Arctic 
have already warmed 4 degrees. If global average temperatures 
increase 1 more degree, the coldest nights in the Arctic
might get 10 degrees warmer. The warmest days in Mumbai 
might get 5 degrees hotter. So how did we get here? Almost everything that makes modern life
possible relies on fossil fuels: coal, oil, and gas full of carbon 
from ancient organic matter. When we burn fossil fuels, we release carbon dioxide 
that builds up in our atmosphere, where it remains for hundreds 
or even thousands of years, letting heat in, but not out. The heat comes from sunlight, which passes
through the atmosphere to Earth, where it gets absorbed 
and warms everything up. Warm objects emit infrared radiation,
which should pass back out into space, because most atmospheric gases 
don’t absorb it. But greenhouse gases—
carbon dioxide and methane— do absorb infrared wavelengths. So when we add more of those gases 
to the atmosphere, less heat makes it back out to space, 
and our planet warms up. If we keep emitting greenhouse gases 
at our current pace, scientists predict temperatures
will rise 4 degrees from their pre-industrial levels by 2100. They’ve identified 1.5 degrees of warming— global averages half a degree warmer 
than today’s— as a threshold beyond which 
the negative impacts of climate change will become increasingly severe. To keep from crossing that threshold, we need to get our greenhouse gas 
emissions down to zero as fast as possible. Or rather, we have to get emissions
down to what's called net zero, meaning we may still be putting some
greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, but we take out as much as we put in. This doesn’t mean we can just keep 
emitting and sequester all that carbon— we couldn’t keep up with our emissions 
through natural methods, and technological solutions would
be prohibitively expensive and require huge amounts
of permanent storage. Instead, while we switch 
from coal, oil, and natural gas to clean energy and fuels, 
which will take time, we can mitigate the damage by removing
carbon from the atmosphere. Jumping out of the proverbial pot 
isn’t an option, but we can do something the frogs can’t: reach over, and turn down the heat.

Options: A. 1.5, B. 2.5, C. 1, D. 3.4
Correct Option: A

Two frogs are minding their own business

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following statements best describes Net Zero?
Options: A. Continue producing greenhouse emissions, and endure the consequences , B. Keep emitting greenhouse gases, and sequester them later, C. Eliminate as many greenhouse gas emissions as possible, and then take as much out of the atmosphere as we emit, D. Halting all greenhouse gas emissions until we switch to sustainable power sources
Correct Option: C
